commentBody: Cute; enjoyed this

Weak theme and easy fill.

A few of the clues were nice.

4/10.
Brilliant trick, I loved it! Thanks for the fun solve.

Didn't appreciate/was annoyed by the dupes until I got it and chuckled.
Not the toughest Thursday, but fun all the same.
This was fun. Took me awhile to ‚Äúget‚Äù it.
Cute theme, but pretty easy for a Thursday. Not a PB, but well under my average.
Definitely chuckled when I noticed the theme - really enjoyed this one. My kind of Thursday - clever without gimmicks and tricks, just stealthily witty.
A super quick solve but so much fun and a clever conceit. It's put me in the mood for Doublemint gum. Double your pleasure, double your fun.

This puzzle had me seeing double.  I caught on to the fact that there were duplicate answers fairly quickly and it helped me finish faster than my usual Thursday time, but I didn‚Äôt fully grasp the theme until I got to CARBON copies.

Any puzzle with a Jimi Hendrix GUTARSOLO reference is okay in my book.  His reimagining of Dylan‚Äôs All Along The Watchtower is in the running for best cover version ever.

That was interesting. It took me a while to realize there was indeed a Thursday-style trick. I enjoyed the near lack of proper nouns - they usually trip me up.

The fill may have been a bit too easy for this time of the week though? I did the puzzle in Wednesday-ish time even though I was solving it in the middle of the night having inexplicably woken up after 3 or 4 hours of sleep.

Thought this was themeless for my first go around, then it hit me. Took the overall L today, though, as the middle section tripped me out. Had put in SUNKENspACE pretty early and couldn't work around it
Didn‚Äôt get the theme until I read the column. Yeah okay, well done.

So fun!  
I did a TAKE TAKE after finding the first theme answer.  Then examined the rest of the puzzle TIME TIME to look for pairs with equal numbers of letters - where would the next one be?  Cute that none of the themers had to USE USE the same doubling word, so each one was a fresh find.
There was even a CRUST CRUST pizza.

A pleasant deja vu experience!
Loved this!
My decision to get a d√∂ner kebab right before this puzzle dropped may have helped me with 44A (though I probably would have gotten it anyway).

Well, it's not not a Thursday puzzle.

What I like best are the supporting words that echo (!) the theme: TWINS, DUBS, REUSE, and BLUR. 

Enjoyed seeing Aly Raisman here; she anchored both the 2012 and 2016 gold-medal teams; she and Gabby Douglas are the only Americans with back to back team gold medals, so very appropriate to have her in this puzzle.

The only thing that held me up was 33D "Intensifying suffix." I thought "As F" like "That dog was big as F." The actual answer is even weaker than that. Of course, if I knew Indian food I'd probably not fallen into the trap.

fun puzzle with a clever theme. I had Escobar down for the longest time, it worked with several of the crosses. My only complaint is 29 down, which is a rather obscure person. Even with most of the crosses in place, I kept wondering, is this right? 
But a nice solve nevertheless -and no rebuses!
More like a Tuesday. But cute and fun.
As I often repeat, "Say something once, why say it again?"

Recognized the [RE]BORN/BORN [AGAIN] for what it was right away, but having done the downs to fill in the NW, it took me a little bit longer to realize that it was the second appearance of the word. Once that happened, I was looking for other duplicates, so the solve sped up as I recognized them. I really liked that the dupes all had different modifiers, which made the puzzle more interesting.

A fun Thursday for sure! Thanks, Kiran!
Several years ago, I bumped into Aly Raisman in Boston, where she lived (lives?). I just happened to randomly be in Boston again today as I'm sitting here solving this puzzle. Coincidence?
Thanks for that little lead-in at the top, Deb - just knowing one of the rules was broken gave me the aha and the satisfaction of mostly getting it on my own.
I must be bad a crosswords because none have been really easy for me. Guess i must be still learning

I thought this was a super clever puzzle, and I loved it!

Though it was breezy for a Thursday, it did have a fun (and funny) trick, and the vertical spanners to boot.
Oh, and nothing triggering; just smiles all around.

Thank you, Mr. Pandey!

"My blackjack puns are a hit!"
"You stand by that?"
"I'll even double down!"

(Gotta split!)

Weirdly, I didn't notice the duplication of words until I finally sat down to finish the puzzle and got stuck on trying to figure out why there were two DOWNs.  DOWN was my last fill, but I already had one.  I had been going back and forth to the kitchen while I was cooking dinner, working on a bit of the puzzle at a time, with a lot of time in between.   

Finally I came to the column  and thought, Good grief, there really are two DOWNs, and from what Deb said, there must be more duplicates.  Went back to the puzzle, and there they all were!  My hair stood on end.  How could I not have noticed them?  NATURE NATURE???  I mean, really.

One thing I did notice was that Kiran had used some very clever twists on some creaky old glue fills, and altogether, the puzzle was a pleasure to work.  

Thank you, Kiran Pandey, and see you in the twilight zone.
Terrific! Thank you.

Sorry, way too many three- and four-letter words for my taste. I did like the theme.

Also, the metric system is inferior to the Imperial system. A circle of 360 degrees or a day of 12 hours, for example, can be evenly divided in halves, thirds, quarters, even sixths.

Who cares about fifths?

A base-12 system would be far superior to base-10.

Well that was fun fun! 

I was bopping around a lot so it took me a bit to notice the clever theme, and then I was delighted delighted! 

Smiles all around!  And pert near a personal best. 

My only brief hang-up was spelling it YOlk at 68D for a moment. What can I say, there's a lot of egg talk lately, so I guess the yolk's on me!

I was guessing guessing what I filled in, I thought I had vision vision then I finally realized what was going on.

Clever :)

Great puzzle! Knew there was a trick with the 2nd 'born', figured I'd just write in 'born' and figure out where to rebus 'again' or 're'. Then whaaaa .. I noticed the other 'born' to the left and it hit me
On 33D, Ismo explains it all: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RAGcDi0DRtU
Still laughing üòÇ. [whew] I needed that. Thanks.
I gotta hand it to Christina on her mini puzzle creations... She's truly excellent at taking a few squares and making your brain do cartwheels trying to figure out her tricky wordplays.

That was just okay, another decent but slightly disappointing Thursday.  The theme was barely there and the puzzle easily solved without it.  Kind of a cute idea though.  I might have liked it a little better if the gimmick word were the same each time (e.g., second chance and second base) but it would still be a bit too easy.

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)
I liked it. One small quibble - the College Board, who administers the Advanced Placement program, calls them AP Exams (proper noun) rather than tests.

The clue for 1-across includes the word HURT, and that‚Äôs the answer for 3-down‚Ä¶ I thought it was a no-no to use an answer in a clue? 

Otherwise, I liked it very much!
Solved in a waking daze, great fun.

At last, a Thursday for people who hate Thursdays! I admit to being disappointed at first by what seemed to be a themeless fill, but then I relied on second NATURE and my faith was (re) BORN.

Not too tricky, but still clever enough to be fun. I‚Äôd call this (first) RATE.

T/Gel shampoo from Neutrogena gone bye-bye. It's not just resting, it's DEAD.

Neutrogena T/Gel was withdrawn from production and distribution starting a year ago, and is now officially discontinued. Unless you want to pay $40 to $70 a bottle for remainder stocks, sold by third-parties through Amazon. Thank California's Prop 65 warning label law, which insisted on a label warning (without any proof) of it maybe being carcinogenic.

Other manufacturers produce salicylic acid shampoos without the coal tar extract. It is okay, but it lacks the anti-pruritic effect of the original. Walgreen's produces a salicylic acid shampoo WITH coal tar, which is terrific. Maybe they don't market it in California. Check the ingredients label.

There is /no/ evidence that coal tar is carcinogenic, I have been assured by a real, live dermatologist.

Appendages of

cuttlefish, octopus, squid

are they arms or legs?

What a fun idea for a Thursday theme.  Possibly a little easier than a typical Thursday, but I‚Äôm one of the few who doesn‚Äôt mind easy  (possibly the only one) 

Well done Kiran

Strands Thread:

Strands #368
‚ÄúLove is in the apps‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµüîµüîµ

Profess no spoilers please until after the View All Replies button.

Fun Thursday puzzle. Took me a while to catch on to the trick, but that was a huge turning point. That's always a nice touch on a tricky Thursday.

One odd answer history search result today. Looked up DOUBLEDOWN. It's appeared in 4 previous puzzles and... every single time it was the 'reveal' of the theme for that puzzle. 'Hint' was part of the clue in three of those clues and 'description' in the earliest one. Some variety of usage in those. e.g. in one puzzle, the implication was to repeat the circled letters. For example a couple of answers for one of them were HEART(MUR) and (BAR)ABUSH.

And... in another one the implication was to put a double letter rebus in the down answers, and then those two letters worked with the across answers. One example of a down answer:

DD
AA
TT
EE
SS

So the implied answer was DOUBLEDATES. And a couple of the across answers:

A(DD)S
N(AA)N
D(EE)RE

And there were some other variations. I might another puzzle find in a reply. 

....

I guess the theme was clever, but it only really reveals itself after the solve (and for me, this column). 

It didn‚Äôt confound or challenge me to think differently in the process. I look forward to that on Thursdays. This felt like a fun Tuesday or (maybe) a Wednesday puzzle in terms of difficulty to me. 

A fun, well constructed puzzle for sure, but I question the decision to run it today.  

Sidebar for those folks who are frustrated by Thursday‚Äôs additional challenges‚Ä¶ Be patient with yourself and you will learn to love the day.  I was also frustrated by Thursday at one point, and would even sit them out. Now Thursdays, alongside Sundays, are my favorite. 

Concerningly, this is the next in a series of very easy solves this week. I hope this does not reflect a trend.
That was such fun, Kiran. So clever. Thank you.

I thought the idea was clever, but not very tricky.  Once I filled in BORN and got to the next entry, BORN AGAIN jumped out at me.

I feel like we haven't had a mind melting Thursday in a while, and I miss that.

Enjoyable. 
I saw the obscure to me shampoo clue and thought - oh no! a brand name crossword, but fortunately not. Only a couple of obscure to me names too, like the - PALACE.
Please explain someone -
PST - re L.A.
LOGO - re Snapchat
USO - re troupe
The phrase 'double down' has been slowly creeping into British English. I noticed it a lot in commentary of your 2016 election. I still find it confusing because 'double' means increase and 'down' usually implies a decrease. Shouldn't it be 'double up'?
Had a lot of fun with this one. I thought the theme was happening in the downs too. 9D/27D for HUT HUT and  42D/60D for REARM. But then those made no sense given the clues.
Fun puzzle. Bonus was making me think of the children‚Äôs clapping song, ‚ÄúDown down baby.‚Äù Luckily Sesame Street preserved a version. Skip to 2:14: https://youtu.be/5K-FpmUUc7U?feature=shared

Well, recognizing these sorts of shenanigans should be second NATURE for any seasoned solver. 
Today‚Äôs puzzle was a blast. Thanks so much, Kiran, for all the double takes!

Great puzzle! My day started earlier than usual due to an early meeting. As per usual, did the crossword with my morning coffee. Part way through ‚Äúhmm, some of the fill looks wrong‚Äù. Check the crosses. ‚ÄúThey look right.  Wait is today Thursday? Yes, it‚Äôs Thursday. OK. Hmm. No obvious revealer. Carry on but be alert. Is that the same word twice? Yes, it is.  Hmm.‚Äù  Penny drops! Puzzle solved! Day starts with a little endorphin rush. Thank you!

Constructor Notes: Kiran mentions ‚ÄúLuckily, I was able to save this one in post.‚Äù 
I have never encountered this expression. I can surmise, but what is its meaning exactly?
I liked the theme. At first it annoyed me, but it became amusing as things started to click.

The diagram of imperial measurements looks weirdly like The Tree of Life from the Kabalah, 

I feel like I should be either disturbed, enlightened, or having it printed on a t-shirt. Maybe some or all of those options simultaneously.
Clever theme and great all round puzzle around the double entries.

I came to the comments section specifically to see what peoople thought about "ASF" as the "intensifying suffix, in modern slang." (The "f" is NSFW, BTW). Clearly, I had no idea what the answer to 43 across ("Indian crepe served with chutney") was. 

I like my answer better.

A puzzle that chews its cud twice!

And so tight! So perfectly symmetrical!

No fluffy fill, just 
majestic answers, leading to
more unexpected, fresh loveliness.

Thoroughly enjoyed.
Thank you Kiran!

üëç üëç
Pretty easy for a Thursday. Got the trick fairly early on. Close to my record time.

I almost thought the trick to today‚Äôs puzzle was that there was no trick until I was nearly halfway and got CARBON (Copy). Well done, Mr. Pandey! And I was 8 minutes under my average with just 2 lookups!

My personal theme for this puzzle is THINK THINK.

That‚Äôs what I had to do after I had filled in the grid, having seen the repeated answers, having been suspicious of the clues to the second answers of the repeated pairs ‚Äì but still not grokking the theme.   ‚ÄúWhy?‚Äù, I kept asking, ‚ÄúWhy are these words doubled?‚Äù

Think ‚Ä¶ think ‚Ä¶ when the conceit hit me, it brought not only a terrific ‚ÄúHah!‚Äù, but a wow at the theme‚Äôs elegance, and how beautifully it was hidden in plain sight.

Those moments of deep deliberation, well, that is what my brain lives for, even if I don‚Äôt crack the riddle.  But what a lovely reward when I do.

I loved seenig the gorgeous CHIMERA, loved running into some sticky areas (more brain candy), and smiled at seeing CRUST on the edge.

You‚Äôve come up with some terrific themes in your six NYT puzzles, Kiran, and I look forward to a PERFORMANCE PERFORMANCE.  Thank you for this splendid outing!

Nice link to yesterday‚Äôs puzzle, since the red-bellied marsh mouse is also known to fear a fire-breathing chimera. Loved Deb‚Äôs helpful table of measures - heh heh. In another call-back to yesterday‚Äôs puzzle, this handy guide to the theory of relativity has been a favourite for years: https://images.app.goo.gl/pRqA1Wc6wcnX2RCcA

As your resident alphadoppeltotter, a role I‚Äôve inexplicably taken in the past eight years, it is my duty to inform you that this puzzle has an unusually low number of double letters, at four, where unusual is any number less than five. This is the first time this year that this has happened. 

I remain your humble servant, ever on the alert.
really fun theme today! grateful for no rebus this week ü´¢

Feel the need to add,
having nothing to do with this puzzle,
the level of *cringe* 
I feel in my bones when
someone says,

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs like deja vu all over again!‚Äù

Ok. Thanks.
I feel better now.

My first NYT crossword completed without my doing any googling  or checking of Wikipedia. There were relatively few proper names or references to American culture (such as in education)  and these had plenty of cross checks for which I could use my general crossword solving skills acquire from the British papers.

So, thank, Kiran, for a nicely constructed crossword.
Very smart crossword.  Nice job Kiran!

Small error in the column, concerning the placement of parentheses: 48A is CARBON (COPY), not (CARBON) COPY, to stay consistent with (DOUBLE) DOWN, (RE)BORN and (SECOND) NATURE. The likely reason that I‚Äôm the first nerd to comment on this is probably that the explanation for 48A is hidden, and I‚Äôm one of the few who clicks on the links looking for an unlikely extra bit of wit!

I was getting ready to be bummed/annoyed that there wasn't a trick, and then the NATUREs revealed themselves and I laughed out loud. The rest of the puzzle was on the easier side for me so I didn't have the opportunity to use it to figure out any answers, but I enjoyed it just the same. 

A note on the measurements diagram - it looks very useful to me! Only note that there's a typo within: a single third of a cup is equivalent to 16 tsps, not 1 tsp. I'm willing to bet that anyone who actually tried to use the chart would figure that out quickly, but I was so pleased with its succinctness that I want it to be completely accurate. 

All best to everyone on this windy south Florida Thursday!
Fun puzzle. Am I the only one who‚Äôs never heard the phrase SUNKEN PLACE?
This puzzle made me smile. If you think you see me complaining, that's not me, it's my evil evil

Got up early today to move my car so they could plow. My coffee was a little late.

As a result, my first thought on solving 58D was, "Was Treebeard a doctor?!"

More help please:
QB and HUT?
I thought ar first QB is a bird that calls hut-hut, but I've got a good imagination.

Well, that was wonderful.  The moment something dawns on me is a delight.  

I asked DHubby for the name of the shampoo he uses, and he said it was "T-SAL"....oh, big help, Dear.  At least I did not have to get up and look in his bathroom cabinet.

I finished marking one quilt's border--complete with a 7/8ths-inch gap...I've decided to Let It Be.   The second quilt might be marked more quickly...or not.  I also need to seam 445 inches of bias strips for the bindings.  And make two labels.  Still finding stray threads on the back that need to be trimmed.  Is there an old saying about one's art being a harsh and demanding master?  Eh, Kiran Pandey?

[Moving to Canada, say]



ESCAPE PLAN


Maybe that should be [Moving to Canada, eh]
You can‚Äôt have the same answer twice. That violates the rules‚Ä¶ rules matter more (not less) in times of lawlessness.
relevant xkcd https://xkcd.com/37/

I was starting to think there was no theme on this Thursday puzzle, and thought, well that would be tricky. But then I noticed that an answer occurred twice.

Born again.
Second nature.
Carbon copy.
Double down.
Have to commend Kiran for coming up with this great theme idea.

Some tough clues put this in Thursday time range, and I had to run the alphabet on DO_A, but my time was still 35% less than average.

I'm not a "rules are made to be broken" kind of guy, but this was fun!  Still, I first heard the word CAVITATE in Mr. Tobias' 9-th Grade Physics, and many times since.

It's a word, and not a weird one. Let it in.
For those who like to rock it out, at last the puzzle theme song occurred to me... https://youtu.be/dD-SpHH7qDA?si=VJejYHWRbnwB8Ut4

I‚Äôve done these puzzles long enough to either dread (REBUS) or embrace Thursdays. This one left me a bit in between‚Ä¶not in a bad way. I kept expecting this to be much more challenging - seemed more like a Tuesday and didn‚Äôt catch on to the theme until the end  ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è. Regardless had fun with it! üëè

Does 44-across mean that certain food carts are designated halal? If so, I‚Äôve learned something. Is there such a thing as a kosher cart, too? While I‚Äôm at it, I would have sworn they weren‚Äôt called ‚Äúcarts,‚Äù because it looks so strange in print!
Delightful puzzle with an innovative theme! I thoroughly enjoyed it, and finished not far from a PB, nearly eight minutes faster than my Thursday average.
A lot on my mind today but this one didn‚Äôt click with me at all. Pass.

Re: the column photo; I found it a bit disappointing that all the kids in the South African "school play" were white, as were all the parents in the audience. In 2010? I guess it wasn't one of those uplifting stories where the black and white footballers overcome their prejudices and become a better team as a result.
Anyone else try to fit AS F in 33D, it was that just me?

I was beginning to think this Thursday puzzle gad no theme. Then I filled in 48A and did a double take. That can't be right.... wait a second.... I laughed so hard when I got it, and started looking for other double answers.

I got quite a chuckle from the constructor's notes in the wordplay column as well.

Bonus: today's mini contained one of the most horrifying (and hilarious) crossword clues I've ever read. üòÇ
To me, this was a perfect puzzle. Quite difficult but fair, with a theme that needed no explanation but also had an "aha" moment. Great job, constructor.
I would describe this one as cute and charming. I quite enjoyed it, even as it was a bit easier than many Thursdays. Nice idea, well executed.
Really enjoyed this one. Several false starts, including ‚Äúouch‚Äù before ACHE and ‚Äúslice‚Äù before CRUST. Thanks, Kiran!
Wow! Just wow!

Great puzzle with a fun theme.

But it was more like a Wednesday and five eighths.

Well, if Francis is here someplace, maybe a Wednesday .6175
Terrific puzzle!  And, Deb, thanks for the flowchart -- I shall master imperial measures sometime.
At least this time all the entries are words, and work both across and down.
Why must there be so many know-it-alls spouting snarky nonsense here in the comments? An air of superiority leaves a foul stench.
Was about to have a rant about a stupid puzzle with tenuous clues... Until I got it ü§£.

I absolutely loved this one! I was convinced that 30A could not be the same answer as 28A based on those darn rules, but then I reread the clue and the light bulb went off üí°So clever. I appreciated that there wasn‚Äôt a theme revealer. I also didn‚Äôt go looking for matching length words like some others, so the theme slowly crept up on me. 

It never ceases to amaze me that constructors find new ways to puzzle us puzzlers. Thank you, Kiran.

I enjoyed the process of moving from ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt use the same solution twice to, ‚Äú I must use the same solution twice.‚Äù

Unfortunately for my streak-let, only today did I learn how to spell HAStLE. üôÑ

But these days, I‚Äôm kind of happy to have a simple mistake that is easily rectifiable.

Well lighting one's guitar on fire did not fit at 10D.

Thank you Kiran

Fun puzzle. It made me do a double-take!

Deb: That imperial chart is hilarious. I just wish we could fully commit to metric by including times and dates. 

Like this: Hey, just 135 kiloseconds till the weekend!
33D almost made an 33D  of me. An entertaining and different kind of Thursday. Double the fun!

Okay, to be pedantic, you could very easily make the customary flow chart a straight line too if they didn't split into all of the fractions of a cup and treated pints as fractions of quarts, i.e.
3 tsp -> 1Tbsp; 16 Tbsp -> 1C; 2C->1Pt; 2Pt ->1Qt; 4Qt ->1Gal

Well, I see that some folks thought this was too easy for a Thursday. I enjoyed solving it but will humbly admit that I did not catch on to the trick on my own. I gave it my best shot, but in the end I got help from Deb. Thank you Deb, and thank you Kiran Pandey. Once it all clicked into place I was very impressed with your approach.
Today I'm Goldilocks. This puzzle was just riiight!
Great theme. Lovers gonna love.

Late puzzle find. I remain puzzled. A Sunday from December 3, 2017 by David Steinberg with the title: "Shell game." In that one there were six sets of shaded squares, in this shape: Hard to describe but I'll just capitalize the shaded letters. Here's one example: eLNorte AccUse WooT So the shaded letters read up from the left, across the top and down on the right spell... WALNUT. One other example as entered: ___oSHea ___AloEs toniC_sWee(pea) So the shaded letters spell CASHEW. But that PEA in parentheses was a 3 letter circled rebus. And that was shaded in yellow. And there was one other square shaded in yellow in the puzzle and that just had the letter F crossing: 127across -- "Like hand motions during a shell game." SWIFT and 128down - "Cook in oil." FRY (crossing the F in SWIFT) And then there were 2 long answers in the middle of the puzzle higher up above. Clued as follows: 65a - "The clue for 128-Down, if this shell game weren't a scam" ARCTICEXPLORER and 86a - "The clue for 127-Across, if this shell game weren't a scam" ATTACKWITHAPAW I have absolutely no idea what was going on there. Here's the Xword Info link. Somebody please explain if you figure it out. https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=12/3/2017&g=15&d=D ....
Really enjoyed the twist!

Oh, what the heck. One more puzzle find. This was different but I thought it was quite clever. A Sunday from August 11,1996 by M. Schneider with the title "The critics agree." All the clues for the theme answers were just one word and all in caps. Some examples: "LETHARGIC" LAZYSUSANSARANDON "SICKENING" TYPHOIDMARYPICKFORD "WILD" MUSTANGSALLYFIELD "BEAUTIFUL" PRETTYPENNYMARSHALL "DISASTROUS" CALAMITYJANEFONDA And there were more. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/11/1996&g=96&d=A ...

Kudos to the constructor -- I thought this was a lot of fun! I actually didn't have any pairs solved when I caught on: I had already tried to convince myself that tying one's shoes could be described as NATURE, and then I solved DOWN from crosses and was trying to convince myself of "downing" as a saying when the pattern clicked. Made solving the other half of the puzzle a lot easier!
Loved today's puzzle!

I really enjoyed today's theme! As usual, it took a bit for me to realize that my first thoughts on some of the answers were actually correct, and that they were part of the theme! (For instance, thinking "Born again" for 17A, rejecting it, then realizing that it was actually right.) I definitely laughed out loud when I figured it out. Fun puzzle.

Okay, I just need to celebrate a silly thing. I'm doing an archive Friday puzzle from 2011. The clue is "William ___, 1990s attorney general"

Now, I'm sure that's a gimme for so many of you but I gave it just a moment's pause to think (processing, processing) and confidently typed in BARR‚Äîwithout having any crosses! 

Then I just stared at it. Is that really it? (I did confirm it because I was so shocked.)

I couldn't believe I knew it.  I didn't think I paid any attention to anything bigger in the 90s! I mean, I was in my 20s and had no shortage of young adult problems to deal with back then. 

Who knew something bigger like that stuck!? 

Wonder what else is in my brain that I don't know is there. Well, I guess that's what these puzzles are for and I can't wait to find out!

Thanks for entertaining my (sort of sad) victory, but a victory nonetheless and I'll take every victory I can get!  Huzzah!!
really enjoyed this one!

I spent ages looking at B_RN ("Like one with renewed beliefs" - I couldn't remember U.S.O.), trying to convince myself it couldn't be BORN again since I already had that right next to it... Very funny and satisfying that it did turn out to be BORN (AGAIN)! Very clever little theme and a truly enjoyable crossword - thanks Kiran!

All RIGHT!!
I am always apprehensive on Thursdays because I fear I can't figure out the gimmick, and when [if!] I do, the effort won't turn out to be worth it. Not this time.  With a little patience, I got the joke--could I call this a Dad crossword?--complete with groan-inducing puns.
Very clever, Kiran. And if this is breaking the rules, I don't want to obey.
Who remembers the KFC Double Down?

This was a toughie, I had to pause and come back a few times through the day before I wrapped it up. But it was great fun, I loved figuring out the theme, and it felt like an interesting balance between that and the punnier long answers that you expect from a Fri/Sat puzzle, in a way that worked out well for me.

Kiran's puzzle is one of the more clever, original crosswords
to appear in the NYT. Hats off to Mr. Pandey!

Some wonderful clues and the ‚Äúsecret double‚Äù is very clever: but for me ( solved inn30) I do wish a title or early clue had pointed toward the ‚Äúrepeat‚Äù trick‚Ä¶last ten solutions were more frustrating than fun.
It was quite a bit difficult for me for Thursday. But when it was finished, I thought the theme was like a work of art.

BORN BORN(AGAIN)
NATURE (SECOND) NATURE
CARBON CARBON (COPY)
DOWN (DOUBLE)

FUN (EXTRA) FUN
One of my favorite themed crosswords in a long while. Hats off to Kiran!

@George 

How could you and I have done the same puzzle?  After doing the one I did, I don't know how anyone could say it was a weak theme.

In fact, I believe that if someone thought it was a weak theme, they probably didn't fully understand it.  (Of course, Deb does a good job explaining it in the column, but I realize a lot of people don't bother with the column.)

If you thought that the theme was just "the same answer used twice in a row", then of course it's a weak theme.  But also of course, there's actually more to it than that.

So when your "review" is a grand total of 12 words and two numbers, it's hard to tell what you saw or didn't see, and thus what your opinion is worth.

I'd say "Clever theme, and typical Thursday-level fill."


PS If you think some of the clues were nice, why not tell us which ones, and why?

(Why bother.  This is a drive-by comment, anyway.)

@Steve L that's a lot of words to respond to 12 words. It was weak for the fact that once you got the themr at BORN BORN, you knew you just repeated the word in the grid where 2 the same length were side by side. Yawn weak.

@Pablo 

But each repeated word stood for a different implicit longer answer: BOTN again, second NATURE, CARBON copy, double DOWN. 

And you had to find the other three instances. 

Also, don‚Äôt confuse easy with weak.

@Steve L 11D 23A

It was only typical "Thursday-level fill" insomuch as it was too easy for a traditional Thursday puzzle, but that had been the norm for at least a year now.

And yes, I did understand the theme, which is why I thought it was weak. It was neither clever nor novel.

I don't care if you think my comments are "drive-by". I will make a comment based on what I think of the puzzle, whether it's good or bad.
@George üçøüçøüçø

@George 

I don't always agree with your reviews, but for how short they are, they are quite informative. I have a certain respect for them.

@Mr Dave 

Steve L also expressed his opinion, didn't he? And he did it quite well, too. George's review was not really worded in a way that would inspire those who disagreed with it to answer in a particularly friendly tone.

@Andrzej 

I only rarely agree with George but I do this time.  There just wasn't much to the theme and the puzzle was too easy for Thursday. However I also thought Steve's response was fair, even if I don't agree with it at all...

@Francis 

Vicious, viscous vacuity! Verily.

@Steve L 

This thread equates to a lot of belaboring on what is one of George's typical brief reviews. I'm not sure why today's suddenly requires extensive discussion. 

You feel George's "short comments without specifics are not particularly enlightening." While I virtually never agree with his ratings, I find his posts a nice change of pace from, for example, my own lengthy comments. No extra elaboration needed!

It's an opinion: if you don't care for it, scroll past.
They're not intended to be "particularly enlightening" they are intended to be provocative.   For today - accomplished.

@Dvd 

Well said -- much more succinctly than me!

@G 

I accomplished my purpose here, much to my surprise. I drew a response from George, who explained‚Äîat least to some extent‚Äîhis reasoning. 

I may disagree with George, but I‚Äôd rather disagree when I have a fully formed comment to reply to than what he usually provides. I hope George will be a little more specific in his future opinions. 

(I‚Äôd like to know how the ‚Äúout of 10‚Äù system works for him.)

The less specifics and reasons one provides for one's opinions of the puzzle ("easy", "weak", "nice") the less others can appreciate or understand the opinion that is being stated.

For example, one could either state an opinion. "the puzzle was easy", or a state a fact, "I finished the puzzle in 50% less time than average".  The later conveys that the puzzle was easy for the solver, and the reason the solver thought so.

When someone talks about "weak tea" or "weak coffee", I have a good idea what they are talking about.  When someone describes a crossword theme as "weak", I am scratching my head and begging for more insight.

So, IMO, "Weak theme and easy fill" is just taking up space, and I'd prefer not to read it.  Yes, we all have the right to take up space with whatever vitriol we feel like spouting at the moment, but it doesn't mean we have to like it.

Kind comments without explanations are much easier to take than unkind comments with no explanations.

@Jim 

Agree to disagree... 

I find the "I got x time / % of my average / PB" posts and day-of-the-week discussions completely boring. I do appreciate that the poster feels strongly enough on the subject that they need to post... and so I just scroll past. 

Kind comments without explanations don't do much for me, either -- but I appreciate the enthusiasm, and the sharing. 

What I truly loathe are comments blaming/shaming the constructor and/or editorial staff. Tech issues like the other day are tedious in their repetition, for those of us who read a lot of comments. 

But a brief, pithy comment plus a score aligning with a personal metric? Sure, why not?

@G 

Whether or not I agree with your brief, pithy assessments, I always enjoy seeing them. A variety of opinions is what makes this space interesting; don't change your style!

@Steve L 

For what it's worth, I see where you're coming from.  I find totally unexplained evaluations of puzzles to be uninteresting.

What I really want to know is what you liked or didn't like about the puzzle, not what the final grade is.

I used to hate it when I'd turn in a paper in school, and all I'd get is a grade, with no comments one way or the other to explain the grade.

To me the comments about how the grade was arrived at is far more interesting.

So, I generally just skip by the four word puzzle evaluations.

@Francis

I haven't said anything in a mere four words since the day I was born, at which time during labor, I reportedly said, "Get me outta here!"

Then, when everyone was standing around in awe of my verbal abilities, "I said chop, chop get to it doc, times a wastin'!"

Yeah, I was a real prodigy! But it didn't last long.

This is in no way connected to today's puzzle, but The Guardian posted a gallery of Polish posters for famous US films. Some may find it interesting. I grew up in a world with this stuff, which is one way of showing you all how my life has been different from yours ü§™. Only after 1989 did we start using the original, US posters. https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/gallery/2025/mar/06/give-it-a-polish-classic-film-posters-with-a-twist-in-pictures?CMP=Share_AndroidApp_Other

@Andrzej 
I believe I like the Polish posters better. Thanks for sharing this.

Andrzej,

Those posters are fantastic. I‚Äôm no art critic, but I know what I like, and I really like those. Thanks for the share. Forwarding to my son, who is more artistically inclined and knowledgeable - I am confident he will appreciate these and be able to explain why.
:)

@Andrzej 

Cool, thanks for sharing! 

Certainly a distinctive style, even across artists and genres. (Even Working Girl gets dark!)

For me, this statement from the piece seems plausible -- but I'm curious what your perspective is:

"Blending raw intensity with haunting beauty, these posters reflect the psychological landscape of a society shaped by repression."

@G 

To be fair, by Eastern Bloc standards, there was not that much repression in Poland. Of course, much horrible stuff happened, some people died, others went to prison, but Eastern Germans or the Soviets themselves had it much worse.

You would be surprised how much free expression there actually was in art, even in movies. For example, the censors delayed the release of the (later cult) movie "Seksmisja" - a biting satire on an Eastern bloc country, only thinly veiled by a sci-fi setting - but ultimately it *was* released, as were "Cz≈Çowiek z marmuru" (Man of Marble) and "Cz≈Çowiek z ≈ºelaza" (Man of Iron): Andrzej Wajda's gut-punching movies about the failures of communist Poland.

Society was indeed shaped by repression to a huge extent only in the Stalinist era of the late 40s and early 50s. Later it was not that bad, for an average person.

@G I think the artists making those posters did not care at all if people went to the cinema or not, and neither did the government that ran the cinemas (almost everything was state-owned, pretty much, even grocery stores) - your thinking was shaped by market economy, and these posters were created in a world where it did not exist. I'm actually pretty sure the artists did what they felt like they wanted to do, and who knows what that might have been? They were artists, after all. They wanted to provoke us into thinking, but not necessarily about the exact same thing they were thinking. Creative people did many great things pre-1989 over here. Just look at the collection of Polish 1945-1989 design at our National Museum under this link : https://hobbydom.pl/sztuka-uzytkowa-prl-u/ I have some of those things at home btw. I love "communist" era furniture. My grandmother was a bit of a fashionista (yes, we had those then), and I inherited her 1960s apartment with all furnishings.

@Andrzej Thanks for  sharing.  The curvy wooden chair is very similar to those by Eames.
 but what really intrigued me is that  we have  a local potter whose work is similar to the tea set. I've saved the image to show her next time she's at our local farmers' market.

@Andrzej Good point! My inherent bias, thinking in terms of market economy. (Why else would there be a poster of a movie except to promote it? Hahaha. Joking aside, when removed from that imperative, the imagination can take flight!) By contrast, here is the US poster for Working Girl (she's the blonde): https://tinyurl.com/38p8r3uc and Tootsie (so cringey!): https://tinyurl.com/3s4zwab3 Thanks, too, for sharing the link about the "communist" era design pieces. Some beautiful work there! Fwiw, the furniture, especially, reminds me of what we call Mid-Century Modern here. My grandmother adored it, and I still own some of her furniture & dishwares. (She was a bit of a fashionista, too!)

@Andrzej 

That is some very interesting artwork.   Thanks for the link.

@Peter And learn you will! The learning curve takes time and practice, so hang in there. Also, you might want to start with Mondays and Tuesdays, which are the easier days. And if you're solving online, use the "auto-check" or "check puzzle" functions as needed. There is, as well, a NYT article that explains the ins and outs of solving (puns, misdirects, rebus, etc.) It was writen by our very own superstar columnist, Deb Amlen. https://www.nytimes.com/article/how-to-solve-a-crossword-puzzle.html You'll also learn much by reading the columns. Good luck!
@Peter hang in there, Peter! You got this!

@Peter My experience was that I felt like a beginner for a very long time, and then things went click!  I can't remember how long that period lasted but definitely a couple of years.  The first time I thought "Well, that was too easy even for a Monday," I felt I had arrived.  Fridays and Saturdays are still often a steep challenge but no longer seem insurmountable.  So, keep learning.  There is a lot of fun to be had.

@kkseattle 
I have to admit I smiled a bit at Deb‚Äôs reference to ‚Äúimperial‚Äù units. While her diagram is accurate on both sides of the pond, I hope she realizes that we don‚Äôt use imperial units over here. This hit home with me when I was living in Holland and replaced a cracked pyrex (small letters) quart measure which I had brought with me , with a PYREX (all caps)  one purchased locally.  It didn‚Äôt take long to figure out that they were quite different. Not only was the  imperial pint 20% larger than the U.S. one, but the ounces were all messed up (1 imp ounce = 1/20 imp pint, 1 US ounce = 1/16th U.S. pint). Don‚Äôt even get me started on customary U.S. cup, legal cup, metric cup, UK cup, Canadian cup, etc. etc‚Ä¶..

@Jane Wheelaghan 

PST relates to times zones.  In the winter, when daylight savings time is not in effect, Los Angeles is on Pacific Standard Time.

A LOGO is a graphic symbol used by companies.  Just like Nike uses a swoosh, Snapchat uses a ghost.

USO is United Service Organization.  It's a charitable organization that sends comedians, musicians (troupes), etc. To entertain service member (troops) and their families.

@Jane Wheelaghan ‚ÄúDouble down‚Äù is a term from blackjack. It happens where the player puts down an initial bet, sees the first cards they‚Äôre dealt, and then doubles their initial bet (by putting more money down on the table). 

The phrase is used outside of gambling to mean someone is recommitting to a position or action with more intensity.

@Lauchlin 

Agree, but will add that the use outside of gambling is usually used to mean "against one's better judgment."

@Mean Old Lady Generally "HUP two three" in my part of the world. And "Ten-HUT!" also feels like an American usage. FWIW, the NYT has an article about the etymology of HUT in American football, relating it to a usage of "hike" I'm not familiar with. https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/31/sports/football/quarterback-signals-hut.html

@Jane Wheelaghan 

In American football, there is not uninterrupted play the way there is in soccer.  Every play has a start and finish, and then the ball is lined up for the next play.  Each team has four opportunities, called downs, to advance the ball ten yards, score or surrender the ball to the other team via a kick called a punt.

At the beginning of every play, the ball is placed in front of the player known as the center, behind whom the quarterback lines up.  The quarterback shouts out a series of signals to indicate when to begin the play (most of which are decoys), and the play begins on a specific signal, usually HUT.

You see, sometimes you need the full explanation to understand the tiny point!

@G 

Juke Box Hero is my all-time favorite! 

I knew that my husband was the one for me, for sure, back when we were dating and I was driving along with one hand on the wheel and my other hand on his leg. Well, Juke Box Hero comes on and I cranked up the volume, put my hand back on his leg, and started rocking out...  

All while driving, head-banging and all (I had the hair for it back then), singing at the very top of my lungs (which aren't dainty), and keeping time by pounding on his leg.  When the song was over, he said, "Wow, that was really nice, babe!"  Ha!! It wasn't!  But he's still with me these 20-whatever years and countless spontaneous and loud bursting into songs later! 

Pretty sure anyone else I'd ever dated would have hopped out of the car at the nearest stop sign.
